The spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots. If you add all of the spells in the list below to your spellbook, you can subsequently add any spell from the cleric spell list instead. The spell must still be of a level for which you have spell slots. Any cleric spell you gain from this feature is considered a wizard spell for you, but other wizards can't copy cleric spells from your spellbook into their own spellbooks.
Additionally, when you learn a Wizard cantrip, you may learn a Cleric cantrip instead. These cantrips count as Wizard cantrips for you.

td.i: dispel evil and good, greater restoration

text.p: Also at 2nd level, you gain the ability to summon a nymian fey.

You may then summon this summoned companion as a bonus action, or dismiss it (no action required). When summoned, your companion gains all benefits of your Companion's Bond ability, listed below. You choose if the faerie is summoned in Seelie or Unseelie form, and you may switch between these forms as a bonus action. Each of these forms shares their ability score improvements, spell slots, and any damage that one form of the faerie takes is transferred to the other form, but the availiable spells and skill proficiencies that each form has may differ. While you are incapacitated, your faerie acts freely, to the best of its ability. If your faerie reaches 0 hit points, they disperse and cannot be summoned again until you complete a long rest.

The companion obeys your commands as best it can. It rolls for initiative like any other creature, but you determine its actions, decisions, attitudes, and so on. If you are absent from where the companion is operating, it acts on its own.

Your summoned companion has abilities and game statistics determined in part by your level. Your companion uses your proficiency bonus rather than its own. In addition to the areas where it normally uses its proficiency bonus, a summoned companion also adds its proficiency bonus to its AC and to its damage rolls.

Your summoned companion has proficiency in two skills that you may choose (two for each form), though the GM may assign skills for certain kinds of summons. It also becomes proficient with all saving throws.
For each level you gain after 2nd, your summoned companion gains an additional hit die and increases its hit points accordingly.

Whenever you gain the Ability Score Improvement class feature, your companion's abilities also improve. Your companion can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or it can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1, or it can take a feat (if approved by your GM. As normal, your companion can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature unless its description specifies otherwise.

Your faerie has a personality traits and a flaws assigned by the DM for each form. Your companion shares your ideal, and its bond is always, "the wizard who travels with me is a beloved companion for whom I would gladly give my life."

Starting at 6th level, your healing spells have the potential to cause a critical heal. When you roll healing for a spell and roll the highest number possible on any of the dice, choose one of those dice, roll it again and add that roll to the healing. You can use the feature only once per turn.

Beginning at 10th level, when you cast a spell of 1st level or higher to restore hit points to a creature, you may expend empower the healing spell with esoteric magics, creating a shield to absorb damage. Your healing spell creates a protective ward on the creature, granting them temporary hit points equal to 1d4 times the level of spell cast. If this healing spell affects more than one target, the temporary hitpoints become 1 times the level of the spell instead. If the heal is critical, you may add an additional 1d4 (or 1, on a spell targeting multiple creatures) to the temporary hit points granted.
You may use this ability a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier. After you have expended your uses of this ability, you may not use it again until you complete a long rest.
At 14th level, any number of dice on the initial heal can result in a critical heal, though dice rolled through a critical heal cannot. This ability does not affect Adloquiem.
At 2nd level, you gain the ability to manifest powerful entities called 'egis'--manifestations of a primal's power.

To summon an egi you must spend one minute performing a ritual for which your spell casting focus is required. After that, you may then summon in an adjacent space or dismiss this egi as a bonus action. When summoned, your egi gains all benefits of your Aetherpact ability, listed below.

You may only summon one egi at a time. If your egi strays farther than one mile from you, or if you are killed or knocked unconscious, their bond to you and the material plane are severed, causing them to disperse. If your companion disperses in this way, or if an egi reaches 0 hit points, they disperse and cannot be summoned again until you complete a long rest. You may recover one of your dispersed egis every long rest.
Also at 2nd level, your summoned companion gains a variety of beneifts while it is summoned by you.

The companion obeys your commands as best it can. It rolls for initiative like any other creature, but you determine its actions, decisions, attitudes, and so on. If you are absent from where the companion is operating, it acts on its own. Your egi may not use any abilities that require a recharge until you reach certain Wizard levels.

Your summoned companion has abilities and game statistics determined in part by your level. Your companion uses your proficiency bonus rather than its own. In addition to the areas where it normally uses its proficiency bonus, a summoned companion also adds its proficiency bonus to its AC and to its damage rolls.

Your summoned companion has proficiency in two skills that you choose, though the GM may assign skills for certain kinds of summons. It also becomes proficient with all saving throws, and has advantage on all saving throws as long as it is within 30 feet of you.
For each level you gain after 2nd, your summoned companion gains an additional hit die and increases its hit points accordingly.

Whenever you gain the Ability Score Improvement class feature, your companion's abilities also improve. Your companion can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or it can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1, or it can take a feat (if approved by your GM). As normal, your companion can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature unless its description specifies otherwise.

Your egi has a personality trait and a flaw assigned by the DM. Your companion shares your ideal, and its bond is always, "the wizard who travels with me is a beloved companion for whom I would gladly give my life."

Starting at 6th level, you and your egi form a more potent fighting team. When you cast a cantrip or spell of 2nd-level or lower, if your companion can see you, it can use its reaction to use its basic attack action.
Your egi can now use its its Recharge 5-6 ability.
Beginning at 10th level, whenever an attacker that your companion can see hits it with an attack, it can use its reaction to halve the attack's damage against it.
Your egi can now use its Recharge 6 ability.
At 14th level, your egi can use their Enkindle ability. After an egi uses an enkindle ability, no other egis you control may do so again until you complete a long rest.

Beginning when you select this tradition at 2nd level, whenever you gain a wizard level, you can replace one of the wizard spells you add to your spellbook with a spell found in the Expanded Spell List below. The spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots. If you add all of the spells in the list below to your spellbook, you can subsequently add any spell from the warlock spell list instead. The spell must still be of a level for which you have spell slots. Any cleric spell you gain from this feature is considered a wizard spell for you, but other wizards can't copy warlock spells from your spellbook into their own spellbooks.
Additionally, when you learn a Wizard cantrip, you may learn a Warlock cantrip instead. These cantrips count as Wizard cantrips for you.

Also at 2nd level, you have become attuned to certain kinds of evocation magic. After you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher that deals fire, cold, or lightning damage, you gain a charge of Astral Fire, Umbral Ice, or Ethereal Thunder respectively. You may store a number of charges equal to a quarter of your Wizard levels. You may retain charges in your body until you finish a short or long rest, you dismiss them as a bonus action, or you gain a charge of a type other than the kind you are storing.
Each type of charge modifies your next spell cast in a different way.
Your next spell or cantrip has its spell attack modifier, spell save DC, and mana cost increased by the number of stacks you currently hold.
Your next spell or cantrip has its spell attack modifier, spell save DC, and mana cost decreased by half the number of stacks you currently hold (minimum 1). A spell cannot cost less than 1 mana.

When you gain a charge of Ethereal Thunder, you gain a bonus to all Dexterity ability checks and saving throws equal to your charges, and your movement speed increases by 5 x the number charges you hold for the next minute.

Starting at 6th level, you have learned how to manipulate your aetheric charges to suit your needs. As a bonus action, you can convert half of your charges (minimum 1) of Astral Fire, Umbral Ice, or Ethereal Thunder to one of the other charges.

Beginning at 10th level, when you use your Arcane Recovery class feature, you may recover additional mana equal to half your Wizard level, but you decrease your maximum hit points by the same amount until you finish a long rest.

At 14th level, you have become adept at bending the elements of magic to your whims. Whenever you cast a spell of 1st-level of higher that deals acid, force, necrotic, poison, psychic, radiant, or thunder damage, you may choose to increase the amount of your current charge by 1.

Arcanists are highly-intelligent, active spell casters who assist their allies by organizing their forces and swaying battle with tactical maneuvers. Wizards who practice this tradition focus their energies into one of three special foci--summoned carbuncle familiars to control the flow of battle, conjured aetheric weapons to fend off foes, or special grimoires of aetheric symbols.

Astrologians hail from a faraway island where knowledge is viewed as the greatest virtue. Whether they stand behind their allies granting them the blessing of the stars and moons of the universe, or standing alongside them on the front line, Astrologians manipulate the fates of both friends and foe to find success.

Some wizards decide to research the use of their magic in the nymian medical arts. These individuals come to be known as scholars, specializing in the lost healing magic of Nym. They often times call on the fey of this lost city, summoning them to assist them in aiding thier allies on the battlefield.

A summoner has directed their studies towards harnessing the essence of dread primals and eikons--false gods conjured by dreams and magic. These harnessed elementals are known as Egis, and act as servants to their summoner.

Some wizards delve into the deepest destructive arts. Wielding fire, lightning, and ice in equal measure, thaumaturges are the building blocks of Black Magic--an ancient destructive art that holds mastery over the Void itself. It is these wizards that seek to master the Void--either to destroy it or to take the dark powers found there for themselves.
